p: The impact of climate change on tick-borne diseases has long been a subject of debate ( Gilbert, 2010, Randolph, 2010) and is still a controversial issue. While some models suggest dramatic range expansions of Ixodes ticks and tick-borne diseases as a result of climate warming, predicted distributions may also vary widely with the modelsâ€™ assumptions ( Ostfeld and Brunner, 2015). It has been stated that the impact of global warming on tick-borne diseases will be more evident at the geographical limits of current distributions, where suboptimal temperatures are currently limiting the spread of infected vectors ( Randolph, 2013). Ostfeld and Brunner (2015) argued that more data on key tick-demographic and climatic processes, as well as the incorporation of non-climatic processes are required to develop better models.
